results.title: Boys on the side
results.creator_credit: Ken Adam, Herbert Ross, Steven Reuther, Arnon Mitchell, Monarchy Enterprises B. V., Heva Productions, New Regency Pictures, Alcor Films, Regency Enterprises and Studio Canal+
results.brief_description: Three women share a car going West and laughs, tears and togetherness unfold along the way. They each have secrets to reveal, strengths to impart and vital moments of self discovery; and their shared friendship subsequently becomes family. Whoopi Goldberg (a wisecracking, lesbian club singer), Mary Louise Parker (a finicky HIV+ real-estate agent) and Drew Barrymore (a free spirit) join forces in this celebration of camaraderie, the art of survival, the gift of laughter and the miracle of friendship and caring by Herbert Ross, the director of The Turning Point and Steel Magnolias. Co-starring Matthew McConaughey, James Remar, Billy Wirth, Anita Gillette, Dennis Boutsikaris, Amy Acquino, Stan Egi and Estelle Parsons.

results.title: Daddy long legs
results.creator_credit: Jean Negulesco, Samuel G. Engel and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A remake of the 1931 film, but greatly expanded to allow for the dancing of Fred Astaire and Leslie Caron. It is the story of a French orphan whose schooling is sponsored by an American millionaire on the stipulation that she will never know his identity. His secretary (Thelma Ritter) is so touched by her letters of gratitude, delivered by the school, that she persuades him to visit. He is enchanted by the elegant, lovely girl and falls in love with her - and she with him, without knowing who he is. The film contains a wide range of music including a jazz piece with drums by Astaire, a ballet danced by Caron, several dream sequences with Astaire imagining himself as a playboy and a rich cowboy, and Johnny Mercer’s memorable song Something’s Gotta Give.

results.title: The Fugitive
results.creator_credit: Andrew Davis, Arnold Kopelson, Keith Barish and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: The Fugitive, one of the most popular television series of the 1960’s was brought to the screen with Harrison Ford playing the role of Doctor Richard Kimble. Kimble, a Chicago surgeon, is falsely accused of murdering his wife. Convicted of the crime, he escapes from custody to pursue an unknown one-armed man, whom he knows is the killer. Hot on his trail is Sam Gerard, US Marshall, (Tommy Lee Jones), who won an Academy Award for this performance. Andrew Davis as director has created a thrilling, action-packed film which moves at a hectic pace towards the final moment when Kimble meets his man.

results.title: A River runs through it
results.creator_credit: Robert Redford, Patrick Markey and Allied Filmmakers
results.brief_description: Norman Maclean’s novel has been brought to life under the skillful direction of Robert Redford and fine performances by Tom Skerrit, Brad Pitt and Craig Sheffer. Set in the mountain wilderness of Montana between 1910-1935, the story focuses on the relationship between two brothers. Their upbringing at the hands of their strict missionary father influences the boys to chose different paths. One brother goes down the road to success while the other’s path is filled with trouble and heartbreak. The two brothers share little in common except their passion for fly fishing which unites them.

results.title: The Bigamist
results.creator_credit: Ida Lupino, Collier Young, Republic Pictures Corporation and Filmmakers
results.brief_description: A childless couple, Harry (Edmund O’Brien) and Eve Graham (Joan Fontaine) apply to adopt a child in their home city of San Francisco. The meticulous adoption agent, Mr Jordan (Edmund Gwenn) suspects something is awry and investigates every corner of Harry’s life before approving the adoption. He soon discovers that Harry has another life and another wife (Ida Lupino) in Los Angeles. Before Jordan reports Harry to the police he listens to his story. Ida Lupino was one of the few women directors working regularly in Hollywood during the 50’s, 60’s and 70’s. She also produced and wrote for both film and television during this period. Her acting career spanned fifty years from the 1930s to the 1980s.

results.title: Queen Kelly
results.creator_credit: Erich Von Stroheim, Gloria Swanson and Gloria Swanson Pictures
results.brief_description: In this melodrama, Gloria Swanson plays Patricia Kelly, a naive and innocent convent girl, who catches the eye of the decadent Prince of a small European country, when her underpants accidentally fall down. He embarks on a scandalous affair with her but when the Prince’s fiancee, mad Queen Regina (Seena Owen) learns of the affair she is enraged and intervenes. In one, now famous scene, she drives Patricia from the Palace, brandishing a whip. Although Stroheim was fired by Swanson after shooting only a third of the film, the final result reflects his fascination with perversion, decadent living and forbidden love between social classes.

results.title: Foolish wives
results.creator_credit: Erich Von Stroheim and Universal Productions
results.brief_description: Posing as a Russian count, Stroheim preys on women; regardless of social class or status. Set in Monte Carlo, the subject matter was considered “repulsive and continental.” Stroheim, bewitching in his monacle is a satanic seducer intent on possessing the wife of an American diplomat from under his nose. The wife is more than obviously attracted to the Count’s fatal charm. “Foolish wives” was an expensive production in its day, and the excellence of the sets and costumes, along with Stroheim’s masterly direction make it a cinema classic.

results.title: Clash by night
results.creator_credit: Fritz Lang, Harriet Parsons and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: Barbara Stanwyck again plays the femme fatale, with her usual flair, in this adaptation of Clifford Odets’ Broadway play. Mae Doyle returns to Monterey, California, after seeking a life of adventure in the city. Disillusioned and bitter, she forms a relationship with her brother Joe’s friend Jerry (Paul Douglas). A quiet fisherman, Jerry is a decent hardworking husband, but Mae is drawn into an illicit affair with her husband’s friend Earl Pfeiffer (Robert Ryan). Marilyn Monroe makes a brief but memorable appearance as a young girl. “Clash by night” is the age-old story of the “Eternal Triangle” where one woman must choose between two men.

results.title: Damage (E)
results.creator_credit: Louis Malle, Channel 4, Studio Canal+ and Skerba NEF
results.brief_description: Jeremy Irons and Juliette Binoche star in this Louis Malle erotic film about dangerous sexual obsession. Irons, a respected MP, becomes attracted and then involved with his son’s fiance Anna. Despite his promising career, his successful marriage to Miranda Richardson and the love he bears for his son, he cannot bear to give Anna up, and they pursue a dangerous affair which ultimately ends in tragedy. Martin, played by Rupert Graves becomes the innocent victim of their deceit. Miranda Richardson gives a strong albeit brief performance, while Leslie Caron makes a cameo appearance as Anna’s mother.

results.title: Cry the beloved country
results.creator_credit: Zoltan Korda, Lion Films and British Lion Corporation
results.brief_description: Based on the well-respected novel by South African author, Alan paton, “Cry the beloved country” is a film whose simplicity disguises the richness of its humanism. Two very different South Africans; one a wealthy white farmer, and the other a poor black priest, are united in the tragic deaths of their two sons. Despite the social and political realities of their country, the two extend a hand of friendship towards one another, and in that gesture raise the hope of peace and an end to the turmoil in South African society. Poitier, as a young preacher is excellent and Canada Lee gives a restrained but heartwarming performance.
